conversation.text: Are you ready to learn how to make chocolate truffles?
Yes! What ingredients do I need?
You will need either 8 ounces of a chocolate bar (chopped) or chocolate chips, 1/2 cup cream, 1 tablespoon liqueur, and either cocoa powder or nuts to coat the truffles (or both if you prefer!)
evidence: 8 ounces chopped chocolate bars or chips 1/2 cup cream 1 tablespoon liqueur
or a few drops of flavoring Cocoa powder or nuts for coating

conversation.text: Great, I have all of those items. What are the steps involved in actually making the chocolate truffles?

Fantastic! Let's begin on the first step: Grab your chopped chocolate or chips and place them in a large ceramic or heatproof/resistant bowl. Place that bowl to the side. Then turn the heat on your stove and place the cream in a small saucepan and heat it on the stove until it reaches a boil. Once the cream is boiling, pour it into your bowl with the chocolate that you placed to the side. Now stir until the cream and chocolate are completely combined.
Done. What do I do with the cream and chocolate mixture now? Can I taste test it?
Don't try it just yet. Are you sure that the cream and chocolate have completed mixed together? Do you see any white spots or is it all creamy chocolate?
Okay! Yes, it has mixed completely. It is now a chocolatey mixture, totally combined. What do I do next?

Great to hear! For the next step you will need to grab 1 tablespoon of liqueur and mix it into the bowl of melted chocolate and cream. You can select any flavour you prefer of liqueur. Which flavour did you use?
I am using an almond liqueur. But I usually prefer the flavour to be a bit stronger than 1 tablespoon. Could I add a bit extra, like a teaspoon more?

That is a great choice. If you prefer to have a stronger almond flavour in your baking, you can add a bit more, but I wouldn't go overboard as it may impact the overall end result. Once you have added your liqueur keep stirring until it has fully incorporated into the mixture. How does the mixture in the bowl look?
I have added the flavour and have stirred the mixture. It all looks like it has incorporated completely and smells great. The mixture is a bit warm still. What do I do next?

That is exactly how the mixture should be. Next we will cool the mixture to ensure that the overall product comes out perfectly - or as close to perfect as we can get. Pour the warm mixture into either a baking pan or cake pan. Then you will let it stand on the counter until the warm liquid mixture thickens a bit. Once you have placed the mixture in the bowl, please let me know how the mixture looks.
I have placed it in a baking pan. It is still pretty liquid, how thick should the mixture get?

The mixture should not be liquid. It should be a bit thick. Not too thick, do not let it stand for too long. Monitor the mixture until it starts to thicken, probably for a few minutes. What is the consistency of the mixture now?
Okay. It is now starting to thicken! Do I leave the mixture to thicken more?

Great! Now that it has started to thicken, you should stir it once more before taking some plastic wrap, and covering the baking pan and placing it in the refrigerator. You will need to let the chocolate mixture cool in the refrigerator for 2 hours before we move on to the next step.
Okay. What would happen if I only waited 30 minutes or an hour for the mixture to cool? I'm pretty hungry and I don't know if I can wait that long.

I don't blame you, it will be quite delicious once you are done but you must wait. If you do not wait the full 2 hours the final product will not come out how it should. It will be too warm and much more difficult to handle. Please wait the full two hours for the best results and let me know once the two hours have passed and you are ready to proceed.

Okay I understand. I will wait the full two hours before moving on.....*two hours later* .... Okay, two hours have passed and I can hardly wait any longer. Can I take the baking pan out of the refrigerator now?

That's great - welcome back! Okay. The next step is to take the pan out of the refrigerator and place it on your kitchen counter or nearby table. You will also need to grab a baking sheet and line it with parchment paper or wax paper (whichever you have available). Then grab a small ice cream scoop or teaspoon. You will use this item to start scooping chocolate from the pan. Once you scoop grab it with your hands and start shaping the scoop into balls and placing them on the baking sheet.
How long should I spend shaping the scoop into balls? And should I space them out on the baking sheet?

Try not to spend too long shaping the scoops in your hands as they will start to warm up from the heat in your hands. This can get messy quickly. Please make sure to space the balls out on the baking sheet so they are not touching and have some space between them. How do the balls look? are they holding together or melting?
They are all about the same size and look round-ish. Some are melting a bit. How should I avoid the melting? I am trying not to roll them in my hands for very long.

Try using some of that cocoa powder on your hands and then continuing to shape the balls. Alternatively you can run your hands under cold water, dry them off and then continue to shape the balls. Or you can try putting the chocolate back in the refrigerator, but this will add more time waiting (which you have said you don't want to do). Have the first two suggestions helped? Have the balls stopped melting?
I definitely don't want to spend more time waiting! The first option has worked. They have stopped melting and are all on the baking sheet. What do we do now? Is it almost eating time?

Great! Not yet, but almost there! Next you want to grab cocoa powder or any other topping you want to use to coat the balls. This can be chopped nuts, sprinkles, or anything you prefer. Then go ahead and place the topping into a small bowl and roll the truffles in the topping you have selected. Do this with each truffle. Are the truffles completed coated in the topping?
I decided to use sprinkles. I have rolled all of the truffles into the sprinkles and each truffle looks pretty decently covered in sprinkles. Now do I get to eat them?

Amazing! Yes, now you can eat them! Any truffles that you don't eat you can store in an airtight container and place them in the refrigerator. Don't leave them out too long at room temperature otherwise they will melt. Enjoy!
Fantastic, thank you! They are delicious.
I'm glad, enjoy, and take care.
Thank you, I enjoyed learning about the new recipe.

procedure.description:
Here's what you'll need to make chocolate truffles:
8 ounces chopped chocolate bars or chips
1/2 cup cream
1 tablespoon liqueur or a few drops of flavoring
Cocoa powder or nuts for coating

Place the chocolate pieces in a large ceramic or heatproof bowl. Put the cream in a small saucepan and heat it on the stove until it comes to a boil. Pour the cream over the chocolate and stir until the chocolate is completely melted and combined with the cream.
If you want to add liqueur or another flavoring, such as vanilla or peppermint extract, stir it into the melted chocolate mixture.
Roll the truffles in cocoa powder, chopped nuts, sprinkles, or another topping of your choice to coat them. Be sure each side is coated evenly.
If you aren't eating them right away, store the truffles in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Since they contain cream, they shouldn't be left too long at room temperature.
